> In non-objective search, on the other hand, often a regularity is preser=
ved because it offers something fundamentally new (i.e. neither good nor ba=
d) and then later becomes the basis for endless elaboration (like bilateral=
 symmetry).  You can't establish something like symmetry early in an object=
ive search because symmetry on its own looks nothing like the final objecti=
ve, even if theoretically it would be helpful in principle in finding it.  =


Although I generally agree with this, I am wondering whether bilateral sy=
mmetry is an appropriate example for it. For example, when evolution starts=
 with spherical symmetry, radial and bilateral symmetry more represent a re=
duction of regularity. From this perspective evolutionary development *is* =
about adding irregularity to patterns rather than establishing regularity?!=
